section-block.rac_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Miranda Paul Illustrated by Luciana Navarro Powell
section-block.rac_book_summary: There are so many helpers who work in our community. Can you guess whose hands these are from the clues on each page?

section-block.rac_body-text: Introduce the theme. Explain that there are helpers who work in our community. Guide children to identify as many community helpers as they can and transcribe the list.
Invite children to dance in a way that shows what they want to do when they grow up. Ask a few volunteers to share their motions and have the group guess the job.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Whose Hands are These? by Miranda Paul.
You know that Lala loves all sorts of books. This is an informational text. That means it tells us about true things.
We’re going to read a book about people who work in our community. Think about this question and we’ll talk about it after we read the book:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What helpers work in our community?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement: When relevant, point to measurement tools and explain their uses.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: In this book, we’re going to hear clues about helpers. We’ll try to guess who is being described.
Who grows food and takes care of animals?
Who has a job to test and weigh and count in a laboratory?
I see a special scale. It is used to weigh small things that are light.
This person does some things you do, like drawing and building. I see a ruler—we use a ruler to help us draw straight lines or measure how tall or wide something is.
We learned about so many helpers today! I’m going to tell you a little more about three helpers.
Let’s talk about the question I asked before we read the book:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What helpers work in our community?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
Write and read aloud short sentences about different jobs in our community as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you call helpers who make food for others?
Someone who makes food for others is called a c___ (cook).
Someone who makes food for others is called a cook.
Which of these helpers work at school?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children likely know the word doctor, but not physician. Tell children that there is sometimes more than one word to describe the same thing, like doctor and physician. Help children name synonyms for other careers like cook and chef, architect and building designer or news reporter and journalist.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Demonstrate Empathy
section-block.rac_body-text: Not everyone feels the same way—you might be having a great day but your friend might be frustrated or sad. Knowing how someone else feels is a really important skill. When you know how someone feels, you can respond appropriately. If your friend is sad, you can give her a hug to feel better.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will revisit some pages of Whose Hands Are These? by Miranda Paul to look closer at parts of the book. We will talk about how each person helps the community.

Clifford knows that being part of a community means that each person has to work hard to take care of the people and the things in the community. As we read today, we’ll talk about how community helpers take care of their communities.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does a cook help take care of the community? What tools do you think a cook uses? Let’s look for cooking tools in this picture.
Police officers’ jobs are to keep people safe. How does that help the community?
A potter is someone who makes mugs and plates out of clay. Let’s look closely at the picture to find other materials a potter uses.
In the classroom, we also have to take care of our materials. What materials do we have in our classroom?
A news reporter’s job is so important—they tell people in the community what is happening. Why is that job important?
What jobs are the children pretending to do? What jobs do we have in our classroom? How do these jobs help our classroom community? (MB)
section.rac_body-text: Review the roles and responsibilities children have in the classroom community.

Show pages 28–29 and explain what it means to have a job fair. Ask children to identify which community member each child in the book is dressed as. Then have a classroom job fair in which children pick a community helper to dress up and act like.
Transcribe children’s speech as they tell how someone in the community has helped them.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: There are many opportunities for preschool children to take care of shared objects and complete jobs for the benefit of the community. Children do this daily when they participate in clean up, volunteer for classroom jobs, and handle communal materials with care. Point out examples of children helping the community during the day to explain this mind builder.

section-block.rac_body-text: Show children how to informally measure a classroom object using Connecting Cubes. Show how to count the number of cubes that match the length of the object.
Sing to the tune of “London Bridge”: Circles, squares, and rectangles, Rectangles, rectangles Circles, squares, and rectangles Don’t forget triangles!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Whose Hands are These? by Miranda Paul.
Lala loves reading true books about real information.
As we read today, we’re going to think about which of the community helpers measure as part of their jobs. While we are reading, think about this question: What do community helpers measure?

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth conversation with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do farmers measure anything? What might they measure?
Cooks have to measure most of their ingredients when they make food. They use tools like measuring cups and food scales. What do you measure if you help an adult in the kitchen?
What tools do you see the scientists using? Scientists might have to measure out a certain amount of liquid—that’s what this pipette is for.
Architects design buildings. What do you see the architects doing in the pictures? Do you see hands measuring with a ruler? Architects have to measure very carefully!
Referees make sure that everyone playing a sport follows the rules. That hand is holding a stopwatch. What do you think that measures?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? What do community helpers measure?
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to have children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Farmers measure the food they grow.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about how some community helpers measure as part of their jobs.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do referees use the stopwatch to measure?
Referees use a stopwatch to measure t___ (time).
Referees use a stopwatch to measure time.
What do you think doctors measure?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children naturally think about measurement as they play, from wondering how much water a cup can hold before overflowing to deciding which doll is taller than the other. Satisfy their natural curiosity by offering activities that allow children to measure using standard and non-standard measuring tools.

section-block.rac_body-text: Before reading aloud the Big Chart, lead children in a discussion of what it means to help. How are they helpers?
Have children close their eyes and think about community helpers they see daily. Go around the circle and ask each child to name one helper they thought of. Try to avoid repeats!

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Super Jobs. It is an informational poster about different helpers in our community.
Whose Hands are These? and Super Jobs each focus on members of our community. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Whose Hands are These? cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s think about how the poster and the book connect to the concept question:
Who are the people who help in our community?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart of Big Ideas, stopping to ask questions and discuss community helpers. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What happens when you visit the doctor? What do doctors and nurses measure at their offices?
What does a plumber do? How do plumbers help the community?
Bakers make delicious treats and breads. They measure carefully to make sure that they add the correct amount of flour and sugar to make dough.
How do firefighters help our community? What questions would you ask a firefighter if one was here right now? I would ask the firefighter why they like being a community helper.

section.rac_body-text: Be chefs for a day! Bring in ingredients for a no-cook recipe like salad, snack mix, or fruit kabobs. Have children measure the ingredients with you. Share the final dish with community helpers in the building or nearby as a way to thank them for their help!
Provide a writing prompt asking children what they would ask a community helper about his or her job. Give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: As you discuss measurement while making the snack as a group, encourage children to use measurement terms and comparison vocabulary. Teach children phrases to compare amounts (e.g., more than, less than, the same as) and measurement terms to describe attributes (e.g., long, short, heavy, light, fast, slow).

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children shake their wiggles out while counting aloud from 1 to 30. Then count backward from 10 to 1 as children get settled and sit down in the circle.
Sing “Old McDonald” and guide children to use their arms to show the size of each animal. Have children use comparison language like bigger/smaller than.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Whose Hands are These? one last time this week.
Lala wants to know: does this book tell a story or teach information?
We have learned so much about community helpers! As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do the people in our community help us?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time, this time acting out the jobs of the community helpers in the book.
What does a farmer do? Let’s act out shoveling soil and picking food. How does a farmer help the community?
How does a scientist help the community? Let’s pretend to be scientists and pour liquid into a little glass tube.
What does a news reporter do? Pretend you are interviewing someone and then typing up your article. How does a news reporter help the community?
Who remembers another word for physician? Let’s act out being a doctor by checking on a patient and helping them feel better.
How do doctors help the community?
What do teachers do everyday? How could we act out being a teacher? Why are teachers important community helpers?
How do the people in our community help us?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Farmers grow food for us to eat.
News reporters tell us when something important happens.
Doctors help people in the community feel better.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about how people in the community are helpful.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do doctors do to help people?
Doctors help s___ (sick) people feel better.
Doctors help people who feel sick.
What is something you can do to help our community?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Languages use different animal sounds to represent what an animal says. For example, roosters say “cock-a-doodle-do” in English. In Spanish, roosters say “kikiriki.” Before singing “Old McDonald,” ask children to name the farm animals sounds in their home language. Incorporate these varying animal sounds into the song!
